name: zea-mays
definition: Maize is a cereal grain first domesticated by indigenous peoples in southern Mexico about 8,000 years ago.
description:
Maize is an annual plant, surviving for only one growing season and can reach 2 to 3 meters in height.

The large narrow leaves, for a total 8 to 21 per plant, have wavy margins and are spaced alternately on opposite sides of the stem.

The leaves are linear or lance like with an obvious midrib (primary vein) and can grow from 30 to 100 centimeters in length.

Staminate (male) flowers are borne on the tassel terminating the main axis of the stem.

The pistillate (female) inflorescences, which mature to become the edible ears, are spikes with a thickened axis, bearing paired spikelets in longitudinal rows.

Each ear is enclosed by modified leaves called shucks or husks.

Varieties of yellow and white corn are the most popular as food, though there are varieties with red, blue, pink, and black kernels, often banded, spotted, or striped.

Only small part of total maize production is consumed directly by humans.

Most of it is used for corn ethanol and other biofuels, animal feed and other maize products, such as corn starch and corn syrup.

Approximately 40% of the crop is used for corn ethanol.

Although it is a major food in many parts of the world, maize is inferior to other cereals in nutritional value.

Diets in which it predominates often result in pellagra (niacin-deficiency disease).

Maize is best grown in warm, tropical and sub-tropical regions as it requires warm soils to develop optimally.

One of the most important requirements for growing maize is a high quality soil which is deep, fertile and well-draining.

Maize also requires plenty of space as it grows and is pollinated by wind.

It should be planted where it will receive full sunlight for most of the day and provided with ample moisture.

In 2014, total world production was 1.04 billion tonnes.

The history of maize and its domestication may be traced back some 8,000 years.

Maize spread across the length and breadth of the Americas, and subsequently to Europe, Africa, and Asia.

Teosinte (Zea mexicana ) has been linked with the earliest maize in Mesoamerica and was first harvested as early as 10,000 years ago.

It originates from Mesoamerica where it represents integral part of human diet for thousands of years.

Maize was brought to Europe at the end of 15th century.

Numerous varieties of maize were created via selective breeding since that time.

contextual.caption: Maize plants are very heavy feeders and even the most fertile of soils may need to supplemented with nutrients as the plants develop, particularly nitrogen.

featured.caption: The maize grains, or kernels, are encased in husks and can be white, yellow, red, purple or black.

facts.name: Annual plant
facts.value: Corn is annual plant which means that it completes its life cycle in one year.

facts.name: The biggest producer in the world
facts.value: North America is the biggest producer of the corn in the world. 40% of the globally consumed corn originates from North America.

facts.name: Varieties genetically engineered
facts.value: Besides selective breeding, new varieties of corn are produced via genetic engineering. Scientists can alter color and the size of kernels, improve nutritional value and develop varieties that are resistant to pests, herbicides and drought.

facts.name: Staple food in most countries
facts.value: Maize is staple food in most countries in the world. Maize is rich source of sugar, proteins, vitamins and minerals. Anyway, maize is inferior to other cereals in nutritional value. Its protein is of poor quality, and it is deficient in niacin.

facts.name: Maize is used in industrial production
facts.value: Compounds extracted from corn are used in the production of plastics, rubber, solvents and fabrics.

facts.name: Color depends on the variety
facts.value: Color of the kernels depends on the variety of maize. They can be yellow, green, red, bluish, or blackish.

facts.name: Important part of the livestock food
facts.value: Maize is very important part of the livestock food. Unlike the maize that is used in human diet, special types of maize are used for the preparation of animal food.

facts.name: Used for the production of ethanol
facts.value: Maize is used for the production of ethanol that is used as bio-fuel. Ethanol does not induce pollution of the air like conventional fuels.

facts.name: Maize crops help cleaning of the air
facts.value: One acre of corn eliminates 8 tons of carbon dioxide from the air. Because of that, corn is one of the most important plants when it comes to the cleaning of the air.

facts.name: Size depends on the species
facts.value: Size of a maize plant depends on the species. Most types of maize grow to the height of 2.4 meters. Wild species may reach 12 meters in height.

facts.name: Male flowers are on the plant's top
facts.value: Male flowers are located on the top of the plant. They release miniature pollen that is easily spread by wind. Female flowers develop between the stem and leaves. They are tightly enveloped with leaves known as husk. Female reproductive organs (stigmas) form well known corn silk.

facts.name: Popcorn is made of maize
facts.value: Maize is mostly used in the form of kernels or flour. Popcorns and tortillas are just few of numerous dishes made of maize. Nearly all baked products, beverages, snacks and canned goods contain maize in the form of corn syrup or corn starch.

facts.name: Each cob of corn has 600 kernels
facts.value: Each cob of corn consists of usually 600 kernels that are arranged in 16 rows.

facts.name: Shallow root system
facts.value: Maize has shallow root system which does not tolerate lack of water and nutrients in the ground.

facts.name: Stem of corn is divided in 20 nodes
facts.value: Bamboo-like stem of corn is divided in 20 nodes. 4 feet long leaves grow from each node.
